fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Sometimes recent commits that exist on the remote repository are not visible in the website, in the 'Commits' page of the repo.

This impacts users' ability to open Pull requests: if a user wants to open a PR for an affected branch, they won't be able to, as no commits will show for this branch.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

There are no steps to reproduce this, this issue rarely occurs in some repos
h3. Workaround

Users have reported that pushing another commit or a new branch to the repo, solves the issue.

You can also contact Bitbucket Cloud Support ([https://support.atlassian.com/contact/#/]) to fix the issue for your repository.

 
h3. Update (October 2021):

We have found the race condition that was responsible for this issue. While we couldn't fully eliminate it in the short-term we were able to significantly reduce its probability. Additionally, we have implemented it in such a way that we can easily fine-tune the parameters of the fix based on the customer impact. Please let us know here if you continue to be impacted by this issue and in the meantime please refer to the Workaround section above to unblock your workflow.
For a long-term solution we have recently kicked off a project to fix the issue fully, but this is a larger project and will take us some time to complete.
fields.summary: Sometimes recent commits that exist on the remote repository are not visible in the website, in the 'Commits' page of the repo

fields.description:
One of the big missing features in Bitbucket cloud is package registries. I say "missing" because it's about closing the loop.

For example, a Java app whose code is in Bitbucket repositiry A depends on a library whose code is in Bitbucket repository B. A and B are both built by Bitbucket Pipelines.

In the above scenario, we shouldn't have to add another system (e.g. Artifactory) just to make two things that are both in Bitbucket be able to have a dependency relationship between them.

GitLab and GitHub both have package registries, with various degrees of maturity and polish. They have both recognised the importance of closing the loop with respect to dependencies between repositories within the same organisation.
fields.summary: Package registries

fields.description:
Based on a question I posted at [https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Bitbucket-questions/FORCE-Bitbucket-Sourcetree-to-use-HTTPS-instead-of-SSH/qaq-p/1200432?utm_source=atlcomm&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=immediate_general_reply&utm_content=topic], I was encouraged to create an issue in the public tracker.

*Steps to reproduce*
 # In Sourcetree, add an existing Bitbucket repo using the HTTPS clone URL
 # In Bitbucket Cloud, attach an SSH key to your user account
 # Create a new branch in a repository
 # Click on the "Check out in Sourcetree" button on the branch post-creation page

*Actual behavior*

Sourcetree opens and attempts to check out your branch using an SSH URL for that repo. Older versions (3.1.x on Windows) will simply throw a "This is not a valid source path / URL" error in Sourcetree. The current version of Sourcetree for Windows will first ask you to add an SSH key to Pageant to connect to the repo via SSH. If you reject this dialog, another will appear saying no SSH keys were configured, and then you get the "This is not a valid source path / URL" error as before.

*Requested behavior*

Allow the user to choose on the branch post-creation page whether to use an SSH URL or an HTTPS URL for Sourcetree, similar to the selector on the Clone Repository dialog. Alternatively, maybe convert the SSH URL into an HTTPS URL on the fly if Sourcetree detects a URL that uses a different protocol from the one used to set up the repo in Sourcetree.

*Background*

I needed to add an SSH key to my Bitbucket account to allow passwordless logins in one of my build pipelines. However, elsewhere I am quite happy with my current account login-based setup, and don't really want to set up SSH keys on all the machines I access Bitbucket from.

However, as soon as you set up an SSH key in Bitbucket Cloud, it automatically assumes you want to use SSH URLs for everything. This means any Sourcetree installs I have that still use account logins to access private repos will no longer work when I click the "Check out in Sourcetree" button.

The current workarounds appear to be either
 * set up every machine that needs access via my account with its own SSH key;
 * copy the SSH key to all machines that need it;
 * stop using the "Check out in Sourcetree" button and resort to standard git commands
fields.summary: "Check out in Sourcetree" button forces SSH URLs if user has an SSH key set up

Currently proposed solution is to add two new variables:
 * BITBUCKET_CONSUMER_KEY - oauth consumer key

h3. Issue Summary
As per the title, if the git author name of a particular file is large or has non-ASCII characters in it when attempting to use the "annotate" feature, Bitbucket will throw an error code.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Commit a file with a long or non-ASCII characters in the Git author name
 # Once committed, open the file on the source browser and attempt to use the "annotate" feature

h3. Expected Results
Annotate feature loads and works fine for characters with long or non-ASCII characters in the Git author name.

h3. Actual Results
An error code is thrown and the feature does not load for these specific files.

h3. Workaround
The only workaround is to run {{git annotate}} on the command line locally, or use a desktop app that has that functionality.
fields.summary: Annotate feature breaks when using long or non-ascii characters in the Git author

 * Choose to prefer/enforce the team-level default PR description.

I committed changes to a file by setting the committer to a different person, using the following command: 

```

GIT_COMMITTER_NAME='Somebody' GIT_COMMITTER_EMAIL='somebody@gmail.com' git commit -a -m "Setup readme with committer and author"

``` 

 

When I list the commit locally, it works, both the author and the committer are visibles:

```

commit 0212e11dfb531a91ee88e906f8d5fd94408a3413
Author: Romain Pouclet <romain.pouclet@gmail.com>
AuthorDate: Wed Oct 9 08:29:09 2019 -0700
Commit: Somebody <somebody@gmail.com>
CommitDate: Wed Oct 9 08:29:09 2019 -0700

```

 

That said, after pushing this commit to my Bitbucket repository, the informations about the committer are not available on the web, in the API or when I look at the raw commit.

It would be great to be able to access this information from the API.

However, it's not suitable if there's a slight change in one of the script. For example, a user has to change their environment on each script so YAML anchors are invalid since it will override everything if the user uses YAML anchors override.

fields.description:
As per the title, this feature request is to add the ability to automatically create deployment environments by simply adding them to your Pipelines YML file.

As an example, let's say you are creating a new Pipelines config, and you would like to deploy to a new environment you haven't yet created on Bitbucket. You have a minimal configuration like this for instance:
{code:java}
pipelines:
  default:
      - step:
          deployments: newEnv
          name: testing
          script:
            - echo something{code}
 

In order for this to work, you would have to manually go to the Bitbucket settings page of the repository and create the deployment environment "newEnv". This feature request is to remove this necessity,  by automatically creating it when a new deployment environment is detected on the YML file.
fields.summary: Automatically create deployment environment when specifying it on the yml file

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Pasting a PR view in the URL when not logged in, will not redirect you to login page. 

h3. Steps to replicate: 
# While logged in, load the repo PR view page: https://bitbucket.org/<account>/<repository>/pull-requests/ 
# Then open the Incognito browser window, page the same URL: https://bitbucket.org/<account>/<repository>/pull-requests/ 

h3. Expected Behavior
# The pull request page either loads or the user is redirected to the login page

h3. Actual Behavior
# User will get a constant spinning  "hourglass" , if you open DevTools console you will see 403, however you are never redirected to login page. 

h3. Workaround

fields.description:
h3.  Problem

The need to avoid build steps based on certain conditions.
h3. Suggested solution

Implement a clause *when:* as part of a step.

e.g.
{code:java}
- step:
   name: some conditional step
   script:
     - echo "run only if the condition is true"
   when: $(git diff --name-only --diff-filter=AMDR HEAD^ some-directory-or-file) != ""
{code}
fields.summary: Add conditions to run a pipeline step

h3. Issue Summary

User is unable to convert a TEAM project from Public to Private and get error message “Projects containing public repositories, issue trackers, or wikis cannot be private". User verifies that all repositories are Private in the dashboard but still see the error message. In tis case user either doesn't validate the Issue tracker and Wiki associated with repositories or can't validate because of huge number of repositories in the project.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a Public TEAM project
 # Create Private repository
 # Create a Public Wiki or Issue tracker in the repository
 # Convert Project from Public to Private
 # Observe that error “Projects containing public repositories, issue trackers, or wikis cannot be private". occurs in UI and project doesn't convert from Public to Private

h3. Expected Results

Project should be converted from Public to Private
h3. Actual Results

Project doesn't convert from Public to Private
h3. Workaround

Make sure all repositories, Wiki and Issue tracker associated with repositories in the project are Private

Repositories can be validated in dashboard if they are Private or Public. However, Issue tracker and Wiki can be determined only after opening and inspecting each and every repository

If the number of repositories are huge then please raise a support ticket in [https://support.atlassian.com/ |https://support.atlassian.com/] to check Public Wiki and Issue trackers associated will all repositories in the project
fields.summary: Setting a TEAM project from Public to Private returns error

fields.description:
Presently, the list of pull requests indicates the time period when the last update occurred.  It doesn't, however indicate who was responsible for this last update.

Example:

!image-2019-10-03-10-34-02-889.png!

When processing pull requests, it's often nice to look at the list and see if a particular ticket has been updated since we've commented on it. 

So in the example cited, the line would read be revised to read:

_"... #2154, created 2 days ago, updated yesterday by John Smith."_

 Having this detail listed on the "/pull-requests/" page would make it much easier to determine which of the tickets have been updated since review comments were added.  (ie. "If I see my name on the ticket, it indicates ticket has not been updated/replied to.  If I see devs username on the ticket, it warrants further investigation...")

Thanks.
fields.summary: Add "updated by" details to Pull-Request summary list

fields.description:
We use protected branches (give "Write access" to None and allow "Merge via pull request" in admin/branch-permissions) to store pull-request number in auto-generated commit message of the merge commit.

Recently, fast-forward merge strategy is introduced. The strategy can be applied even for those protected branches. As a result, there is a loophole that people can make a commit to the protected branch without including the pull-request information via fast-forwarding.

I think it would be nice to (1) identify protected branch and disable fast-forward merging, or (2) add ability to disable fast-forward merging per repository.
fields.summary: Disable fast-forward merge to protected branch

fields.description: I chose Bitbucket to host my repositories because of its Mercurial support.  If Bitbucket forces me to switch to git, which I find inferior as well as more difficult to use.... there is no reason to stay with Bitbucket.  There are plenty of more popular and better git repository sites.
fields.summary: Reconsider Mercurial Deprecation

fields.description:
{panel:title=Bug Fix Policy|titleBGColor=#e0efff}
(i)
 At the moment, we can't set an ETA for the fix to be released, since there's a number of factors that determine how our product team prioritizes bugfixes.
 You can learn more by reading [Atlassian Cloud Bug Fixing Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-cloud-bug-fixing-policy-206865884.html].
{panel}
h3. Issue Summary

Pull request guidelines cannot handle multibyte characters properly.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Add a file named *CONTRIBUTING.md* to an arbitrary repository, which contains below:
{code:none}
こんにちは
===

Multibyte text: あいうえお
Here's the 5th line!
{code}

 # Create a pull request to the repository and click the link "Pull request guidelines"
 # Verify the page shows a garbled text

!jac-multibyte.png|thumbnail!
h3. Expected Results

Pull request guidelines is able to show the text properly.
h3. Actual Results

Pull request guidelines shows a garbled text like:
{code:none}
ã“ã“ã«ã¡ã¯

Multibyte text: ããããã Here's the 5th line!
{code}
 
It’s garbled only with the pull request guidelines, but not on the repository source browsing.

h3. Workaround

None. Consider adding yourself as a watcher to be kept informed as to the state of the bug moving forward. With that way, if our development team updates the ticket, you'll be notified via email.
fields.summary: Pull request guidelines get garbled with multibyte characters

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary:

The Unsubscribe link provided over email notifications for Bitbucket users is not clickable and doesn't redirect to to disable notifications

h3. Steps to Reproduce
E-mail notifications sent to new Bitbucket users will have a unsubscribe as shown in the screenshot below. On clicking the link ideally you should be taken to the Notifications section of your Bitbucket account.


h3. Workaround

You can manually have the notifications turned off by navigating within the UI as follows:
- Login to your Bitbucket account
- Click on to the Avatar > Choose Bitbucket Settings
- Within the Settings pane, click on Notification
- Here you may choose to disable/enable the required notifications as per your requirement
fields.summary: Unsubscribe link provided over e-mail notifications are not working

fields.description:
Create feature to take periodic repo snapshot syncing to an external storage location over HTTPS (S3 or other).

Input Settings from cloud account administrator are
 * Frequency setting
 * Storage location and Key to storage location. 
 * Notification Details
 ** Email address to send notices
 ** Option to send only on error.

Output
 * Backup consists of a dated zip file or some other 'collection' structure compatible with the repository import feature.
 * Backup delivered over HTTPS within some time-frame of the frequency setting kickoff (limits accepted - such as max of 1/day).   Some level of retry built in, but otherwise failing on repeat issue with notification.  

 ** Failure would contain any details and attempts.
 ** Success would contain duration of the delivery.  IE start time/end time/duration/ size.
 * Log of activity (attempts and outcome of attempts) available in the cloud console.
fields.summary: Request Build in feature to take automated backup to S3/Azure/Google Storage

fields.description:
Currently, Bitbucket Cloud provides 2GB repositories for all repositories in the platform. It's currently not possible to have repositories larger than that, even by paying, and the only way to bypass this is to use Git LFS or by reducing the size of the repository.

While Git LFS may be a valid workaround for most use cases, there are times where this is not usable.

This feature request is to add the ability to, somehow, raise the maximum size of repositories.
fields.summary: Have a way to effectively raise the repository size for Bitbucket Repositories

fields.description:
Users are unable to login to Bitbucket on Safari 13 with FIDO2 USB keys for 2FA and receives the error: "You can't log in with this device because your browser does not support U2F security keys."

However, Safari 13 has support for FIDO2 USB 2FA keys as per: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari_release_notes/safari_13_release_notes.

As per https://www.yubico.com/works-with-yubikey/catalog/bitbucket/ documentation, FIDO U2F is supported by Bitbucket which is an extension of FIDO2.

Note: FIDO2 USB keys work in Google Chrome.
fields.summary: Bitbucket cloud doesn't support  FIDO2 USB keys for Safari 13

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

If we upload file in a repository "Downloads" section with special characters, the special characters are being ignored.

Edit - This also affects attaching files in issue tracker's attachments.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Use a new or existing repository
 # Click *Downloads*
 # Upload file with a file name "*test## 12345.txt*"

Or use the CURL Command below to upload a file:
{code:java}
curl v --fail -X POST -u username:password "https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/username/repo_name/downloads" --form files=@"test## 12345.txt"
{code}
h3. Expected Results

The filename "*test## 12345.txt*" will be the same after uploading.
h3. Actual Results

The filename "*test## 12345.txt*" is being renamed to "*test_12345.txt*" without special characters.
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Uploaded file names with special characters in repository Downloads is being ignored

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Bitbucket users can subscribe Slack channels to Bitbucket repositories only if they have administrator access to these repositories.

This means that users with read/write access to a repo cannot create a personal subscription to such a repo.
h3. Suggested Solution

Allow users with read/write access to a repo to create a personal subscription to that repo.
fields.summary: Allow Bitbucket users to create personal subscriptions for Slack to repositories they have read/write access

fields.description: It would remove some friction if the "Go to pull request" link in a commit would jump right to the PR if there is only one associated PR.  At least in our workflow I have never seen a commit associated with more than one PR, so this dialog just gets in the way.
fields.summary: If there is only one PR, the "Go to pull request" from a commit page should go to that PR

fields.description:
Currently, we don't have an API endpoint to configure, *Repository Settings* > *Chat Notifications* > *Settings.*

Filing this as a feature request to have this functionality in the future to help users to make modifications on multiple repositories at once.
fields.summary: API endpoint to configure 'Settings' under 'Chat Notifications' section in the repository

fields.description:
Currently, we don't have an API endpoint to modify, *Repository Settings* > *Pull-Request* > *Exclude files.*

Filing this as a feature request to have this functionality in the future to help users to make modifications on multiple repositories at once.
fields.summary: API endpoint to modify Pull-requests - Exclude files

fields.description:
In the editor of the description field of a PR. When I press down (down arrow) while in a list (bullet or number), the cursor jumps to the first line below the list instead of to the next list item.

Currently, the issue can be replicated using the Firefox browser and it works fine using Chrome. But the customer mentioned that it was working fine on Firefox. 

Steps to replicate the issue:

1. Go to a repository->Pull request->Create pull request.
 2. In the description, create a list as shown in the attached screenshot.
 3. With the cursor on the first line of the list(As shown in 1.png), click down arrow.
 4. The cursor jumps to the first line below the list instead of to the next list item(see the screenshot 2.png)
h3. Workaround

Use Chrome instead of Firefox
fields.summary: Cursor jumps below a list in a text editor

fields.description:
Currently, only users with admin privilege can consult the repository configuration. Having read-only access to the repository configuration have many uses, give transparency and clarity, and shouldn't expose sensitive information by default.

I want to design a tool that validates repository configuration, but I can only do that by providing extremely powerful credentials to this tool, which could get dangerous in the blink of an eye.
fields.summary: Let non-admin users see the repository configuration

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The timestamps for issues in Bitbucket Cloud's issue tracker typically shows a relative time, eg. "x days ago". In order to see the exact date/time of the comment, the user needs to hover their cursor over the relative date/time. 

h3. Suggested Solution
Instead of requiring the user to hover the cursor on the timestamp to get the exact date/time, Bitbucket Cloud should allow us to toggle the option to directly display the exact date/time.
fields.summary: Show absolute date/timestamp for issues

fields.description:
Hi,
I my operation I restrict the access from public.
Which are the IP's using in pipeline running?
fields.summary: List of public ip used in Pipelines.

fields.description:
h3. Summary:
Users who have a large repository set and would like to make them Public or Private. Currently, this we needs to edit the access level from the respective repository settings.

The suggestion is to have an option to bulk update the access levels. 
- Provide an API endpoint for access levels
- UI option to bulk update
- All for Bulk updating the repositories when we move them between different projects(public/private)
fields.summary: Allow Bulk update to Repository access level

fields.description:

The next page's value in the following API call is not a digit, but rather random characters

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Run the following API call:

h3. Expected Results

h3. Actual Results

fields.description:
The Bitbucket interface has been updated to fully hide the menu for repo options or expanding it to full size to show icons & links.

This replaces the efficient, linked icon-only column which was super convenient.
fields.summary: Navigation - Show repo link options without having to expand menu

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Checking the old UI for the Pull Requests, we are able to see our "links" being properly rendered inside the inline code blocks, however, the new UI seems to remove the "links" and let only the inline code block and its content
h3. Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a Pull Request
2.  Using either the UI or the API call, add a comment like this:
[`6e97c63`](https://bitbucket.org/<repo_owner>/<repo_test>/commits/<hash>)
3.  The old UI will render it properly, however, the new one will not.
h3. Expected Results

 

The new UI will present the same behaviour that the old UI experience has, inline code blocks render "links".
h3. Actual Results

 

The new UI is not rendering the links inside inline code blocks, it is only showing the content int he inline code block, not the "links".
h3. Workaround

1. Check the comments in the old UI
2.  Remove the " ` " from the comment, so the link will not be in the inline code block and, will render properly in both, new and old UI.
fields.summary: Links on the new UI are not rendering properly while inside code blocks

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Having a pipeline that deploys to two different dev environments and it does those sequentially and on a manual trigger. Something like this:
{code:java}
branches:
   master:
     steps:
       - step:
          name: Deploy to ddev
          deployment: ddev
          trigger: manual
          script:
            - # Do the thing...
      - step:
          name: Deploy to adev
          deployment: adev
          trigger: manual
          script:
            - # Do the thing...
{code}
Then a change is made to make this happen in parallel but forgets to remove the manual trigger or thinks that that is valid and we end up with something like this:
{code:java}
branches:
   master:
     steps:
       - parallel:
         - step:
            name: Deploy to ddev
            deployment: ddev
            trigger: manual
            script:
              - # Do the thing...
        - step:
            name: Deploy to adev
            deployment: adev
            trigger: manual
            script:
              - # Do the thing...
{code}
Pipelines won't report this as an error on any branch except for master. So if I had a default set of steps that just runs tests, those tests and the pipeline will pass and the PR can be merged. Then when we get to master and a deploy is to be triggered, the pipeline fails and a new PR needs to be created to fix the broken pipeline.
h3. Expected Results

Either validate all branches in yml or have separate yml files per branch
h3. Workaround

Further PR are necessary in order to apply a fix to the YML file.
fields.summary: YML Validator only validates current branch

fields.description:
On PR team page([https://bitbucket.org/dashboard/pullrequests?section=teams]), I would like to see reviewers and reviewers approval status just like the single PR page.

It will give an overall review status and help to make decision.
fields.summary: Show reviewers and review status on Pull Requests list page

fields.description:
Hi,

Is there any plan to add a "Merge when CI succeeds" button?

Right now if often happens that the review is done, but the CI is still running. This requires us to come back at a later point, and then "Merge". This would make the review/merge process a lot more fluid for us.

This is something GitLab already has, and I quite liked it.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Merge when Pipelines succeeds button

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Assume you have a .tar.gz file uploaded in the Downloads section of a Bitbucket repo.
 Downloading this file from Chrome, will give an unzipped file.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a file locally, e.g. myfile.txt
 # Zip this file with the command
{code:java}
tar -czf myfile.tar.gz myfile.txt{code}
 # Running the file command on this zipped file, we see:
{code:java}
$ file myfile.tar.gz
myfile.tar.gz: gzip compressed data, last modified: Tue Sep 24 14:51:58 2019, from Unix{code}
 # Upload the file *myfile.tar.gz* in the Downloads section of a Bitbucket repo
 # Download the file using Chrome

h3. Expected Results

Running the *file* command on the downloaded file, we should see that it's a gzip file, like this:
{code:java}
$ file myfile.tar.gz
myfile.tar.gz: gzip compressed data, last modified: Tue Sep 24 14:51:58 2019, from Unix
{code}
h3. Actual Results

When downloading the file from Chrome and run the *file* command, we see the following:
{code:java}
$ file myfile.tar.gz
myfile.tar.gz: POSIX tar archive
{code}

h3. Notes
The issue seems to be specific to Chrome.
 If we download the file from another browser, e.g. Firefox, the downloaded file shows as a gzip file.
 Also, downloading a .tar.gz from a website other than Bitbucket, using Chrome, also gives a gzip file.

h3. Workaround

Use a different [supported browser|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/which-browsers-does-bitbucket-support-296092232.html]
fields.summary: Downloading a .tar.gz file from Bitbucket using Chrome, gives an unzipped file

fields.description:
Hi!
This is my first suggestion, so I am not sure if I am doing it right. Please, fix it if necessary.

Idea is next:  on project's "Pull requests" page, show count of currently visible PRs (considering filtering and searching conditions; but without pagination). It would be good to place this number somewhere on top of the page.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Show count of visible PRs on "Pull requests" page

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of September 2019|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#B2D4FF | titleBGColor=#B2D4FF | bgColor=#EAF1FC}
Microsoft has not released any major updates for IE11 since 2015, and has [recently discouraged the use of IE11 as a default browser|https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/Windows-IT-Pro-Blog/The-perils-of-using-Internet-Explorer-as-your-default-browser/ba-p/331732].

To allow us to continue to take advantage of modern web standards to deliver improved functionality and the best possible user experience across all of our products, we have decided to end support for IE11 on *31 March 2020*.

End of support means we will not fix bugs that are specific to IE11, and will begin to introduce features that aren't compatible with this browser.

Find out more about this change from our [announcement|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Feedback-Forum-articles/Retiring-IE11-support-for-Atlassian-cloud-server-and-data-center/ba-p/1185312].

If you have questions or concerns about this change, please comment on this issue.

{panel}

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Navigating on Bitbucket generates an HTTP pop up when the user logs off Bitbucket  from one of multiple tabs

h3. Environment
Prod

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Open an incognito tab and login to bitbucket
 # Create a duplicate tab
 # Log off from this duplicate tab
 # Try to click any buttons on the first tab such as repositories or settings


h3. Expected Results
Bitbucket would take you to the login landing page
h3. Actual Results
Bitbucket throws an http pop up.

The below exception is thrown in the HAR file:
HTTP 401 - Unauthorized
h3. Notes
A similar issue was fixed last week by development team as the issue occurred when directly browsing to https://bitbucket.org/dashboard/repositories. This action caused an HTTP pop up to occur. 
h3. Workaround
Log in back to Bitbucket through this HTTP pop up.
fields.summary: Navigating on Bitbucket generates an HTTP pop up

fields.description:
h3. Summary:
 Currently Bitbucket 2FA and Atlassian Account 2FA are different from each other. So unmanaged users currently need to enter the authy codes twice. Once for Atlassian Account and another for Bitbucket Cloud.

The Suggestion is to unify the 2FA process, where the same 2FA can be used for Bitbucket and Atlassian account.

h3. Workaround:
 Users can currently opt to have SSO on Atlassian account. This means their account needs to be managed and the domain claimed. Then, enable 2FA on Bitbucket account. Essentially asking for 2FA only once over Bitbucket Cloud.

The unmanaged users currently have to enter 2FA codes twice as suggested earlier.
fields.summary: Request to have a unified two-step authentication across Atlassian Products

fields.description:
h3. Summary:
 We see that the SHA generated for Pull Request and PUSH are of different length. Which in turn causes the webhook Payload to be of different lengths.

Users request the SHA to be of the same length for different webhook payloads.

h3. Workaround
We currently don't have a workaround this
fields.summary: Webhook payloads have different SHA hash Sizes

fields.description:
Inside of the Dashboard issues, it'd be nice to see all completed issues from all of the reports at the same time. And possibly a search form that lets the user search the "All Issues" across "All Repos". Right now it only shows the 'Unresolved Issues'.

These are the new filters that can be added to the Main Dashboard > Issues section:
• All Issues both Resolved and Unresolved
• All Resolved Issues
• All Resolved Issues by Me
• All Resolved Issues by Other People

It's a bit tedious to have to go through each repo to find the issues the user has fixed personally.
fields.summary: Has more filter for issue in the main dashboard

fields.description: Currently, smart mirror doesn't support redirection with Atlassian access. The user that has it enable on the cloud with SSO will have an issue where user unable to login and has to use App Password to login instead of their SSO login.
fields.summary: Support for Atlassian access redirection on Smart mirror

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Currently, users can buy additional LFS storage packs, $10 for 100 GB. The "Plan details" page has a section that shows how much LFS storage you have left, however, when you buy an extra 100 GB, it doesn't show that you have 100 GB more of storage.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Log in to your account
 # Click on your avatar > Bitbucket Settings > Plan details > Add your credit card and allow overages to be used on your account
 # Use LFS until you buy an additional 100 GB
 # On the Plan details page, it should still show that you have 0 MB left, despite having bought more LFS space.

h3. Expected Results

Buying additional LFS storage should update the "storage remaining" on the UI.
h3. Actual Results

If Additional LFS space is bought, the "storage remaining" stays at what it was before.

 
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Buying additional LFS storage does not update "storage remaining"

fields.description:
I'm a reviewer for a bunch of different repos in my organization (using Bitbucket Cloud). When I get an email letting me know that there's a PR to look at, the email doesn't indicate anywhere which repo the PR is for. It would be helpful if this information were easily available. 

 

Personally, I'd rather have the name of the repo in the email subject instead of the title of the PR, but at a minimum the repo name should be prominent in the email itself. 

 

It would also be nice if the Bitbucket dashboard gave more prominence to the repo name when listing PRs, and maybe had an option to sort PRs by repo instead of just chronologically.
fields.summary: Pull request email does not indicate repo

fields.description: It would be helpful to be able to read the name of the custom pipeline from an environment variable inside the docker container running the pipeline. We use YAML anchors to incorporate common code between a few different pipelines.
fields.summary: Pipeline name as environment variable

fields.description:
There are languages supported by Pygments that appear unavailable to me on bitbucket.org.

For example, if I edit a file in Bitbucket cloud, the dropdown list for "Syntax Mode" does not contain "Stata" as a language. However, "Stata" is supported by Pygments: [http://pygments.org/demo/6628262/]. Similarly, the language list at [http://pygments.org/demo/] includes "Stan", while BitBucket.org does not.
fields.summary: Update supported languages to latest Pygments list

fields.description:
Currently, there are no provided navigation links for a user to jump to the next/previous annotation in a pull request. If added, a user can avoid having to scroll a lot just to get to the next/previous annotation in a pull request.

It's quite easy to get lost in the code when searching for the next/previous annotation in the pull request, especially on large pull requests, where there are a handful of annotations, but the code diffs are huge in size.

We have experienced this issue when reviewing a huge pull request for updating/migrating our systems.
fields.summary: Add "Jump to Next/Previous Annotations" link to Annotations when previewing code diffs in pull requests

fields.description:
Currently, there is no "Scroll to Top" link within the Annotations menu, when viewing the comments for a pull request. There needs to be a way for someone to jump back to the top if they have finished viewing annotations.

This lack of "Scroll to Top" will become an issue if someone has to review a pull request contains more than 1500+ lines of code changes, with "ignore whitespaces" option turned on. We've experienced this while having to review a 3000+ lines of changes made to an update in a pull request.

Maybe this option can only be enabled if the user has scrolled far down enough that it takes a while for them to scroll back up to the top?
fields.summary: Add "Scroll to Top" link to Annotations when previewing code diffs in pull requests

fields.description:
At the moment, after logging in to https://bitbucket.org/, the user will land in Bitbucket Dashboard which shows PRs and active repos the user has access to.

This is not always desirable and some users would like to be able to set a different landing page.

E.g. a user might not want to view all repos they have access to, but prefer to land on the page that shows only the repos they own.
fields.summary: Allow users to specify the landing page for https://bitbucket.org/

fields.description:
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open [filtered repositories list|https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories?after=2015-05-02T12%3A37%3A07.608575%2B00%3A00&pagelen=50] in the API.
# Follow the "next" parameter link.

h3. Expected Result
The "next" link shows the next page of results.

h3. Actual Result
The "next" link throws a "Something went wrong" error. 

h3. Workaround
None so far but our developers are working on a fix.
fields.summary: API repositories "next" property is giving an error

fields.description:
The product our company is developing has microservice architecture. We have around 100 repositories in BitBucket.

Sometimes we need to modify something in repo settings, something like enable pipelines, add notification channel, change merge strategy or configure branches.

Is there any option to "mass edit" repositories in Bitbucket? Or maybe there is some external tool? Could you implement this option someday?
fields.summary: Option for mass edit of repositories

fields.description: When a pipeline was started by a branch trigger, it it not possible (as far as I can see) to see which job is running. I can only see the steps, but that often doesn't help, since the UI is sometimes cutting off the names of the steps, or some steps are similar between jobs.
fields.summary: Ability to see which pipeline job is running

fields.description:
Currently, anyone that has at least write access to a repository is able to edit its bitbucket-pipelines.yml file.

This is a problem because Pipelines, as a CI/CD platform, may have access to restricted environments that any common user shouldn't really have. Allowing anyone with write access to edit bitbucket-pipelines.yml files basically gives them the ability to run arbitrary commands that may be unwanted.

 

The suggestion, in this case, would be to restrict everyone from using the bitbucket-pipelines.yml file, except users who get explicitly whitelisted to edit this file.
fields.summary: Restrict who has the ability to edit the bitbucket-pipelines.yml file

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
The user is unable to view Public snippet that has an image without logging in to Atlassian account. The page will give an error message.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a public snippet
 # Upload image
 # View the snippet without logging in to Atlassian account

h3. Expected Results
The user is able to view the Public snippet without logging in since it's public

h3. Actual Results
The user is unable to view the Public snippet without logging in as it returns an error message

h3. Workaround
The workaround is to log in with Atlassian account before viewing the Public snippet
fields.summary: Viewing public snippet that has image without logging in give error

fields.description:
As can be seen from the overview in this documentation:

[https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/bitbucket/modules/webhook/]

The pullrequest:comment_updated hook is not present. This makes it difficult to create apps that interact with user comments, because there is no way to know that a user has made edits to a comment.

I think this is a bug rather than a feature request, because the "add new webhook" menu under Bitbucket account settings _does_ list "Comment Updated".

!image-2019-09-18-10-40-54-313.png!

Adding this webhook results in pullrequest:comment_updated listed under "triggers" in the "request logs" overview for that hook. 

!image-2019-09-18-10-40-07-888.png!

 

Possibly related issue: BCLOUD-17773
fields.summary: The Bitbucket Cloud Webhook module for Atlassian Connect apps does not support pullrequest:comment_updated

fields.description:
When I push to merge button, pull request pop-up gave this error. Pull request owner`s last name has `Ü` character.

h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: When Merging pull request, gives ascii codec error

fields.description:
h3. Problem

As a project admin, I want to be able to configure my team's pipeline and be sure that a developer will not change it by mistake or without authorization. 
h3. Suggested solution

Reject commits with changes to this file in case the user is not a repository admin.
fields.summary: Add extra permission to edit bitbucket-pipelines.yml file

fields.description:
h3. *Situation*

Some customers wanted to enforce closing the source branch after merged from a pull request.
 The reason being is that some developers aren't aware that will need to close their source branch after merging based on their workflow.
h3. *Feature Request*

It would be an essential feature to have if there's an option to enforce closing the source branch after merging a PR.
fields.summary: Enforce Closing Source Branch

fields.description:
Here's the question: [https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Bitbucket-questions/Pipelines-Build-Setup-taking-too-long/qaq-p/857558]

But I didn't find any update on it. 

 

For me, I'd like to know why does it take so long time to set up, particularly for non-first step.

From my understanding, We have enough time to prepare the rest steps.

 

If extra 40s is required for each step, does it mean we should keep fewer steps?
fields.summary: Pipelines Build Setup taking too long

fields.description:
Like we have on Bitbucket Server version, we would like to have a functionality that allow us to set up the default session timeout to our personal/company accounts as we want.

[https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserverkb/how-do-i-change-the-default-session-timeout-779171650.html]

The reasons for this functionality be necessary for us is related to:
 1. Our security policies
 2. Qualify our product development to specifics ISO

Comments from [~fstefanelli@atlassian.com]:



This is also available for other products such as Jira and Confluence, but not for Bitbucket according to this page:

[https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/session-duration-management-976763148.html]
fields.summary: We would like to have the ability to set a different default session timeout

fields.description:
h3. Problem
Although account variables can be referenced in bitbucket-pipelines.yml the editor only suggests repository variables for autocompletion.

h3. Suggested solution
Add autocompletion for account variables.
fields.summary: Autocomplete for account variables in bitbucket-pipelines.yml editor
Evaluate account variables referenced by repository variables
